distress.translation[0].definitions[0].e: Luke’s behaviour caused his parents great distress.
The girl was crying and clearly in distress.
distress.translation[0].definitions[1].d: suffering and problems caused by a lack of money, food etc
distress.translation[0].definitions[1].e: charities that aid families in distress
distress.translation[0].definitions[3].d: a situation when a ship, aircraft etc is in danger and needs help
distress.translation[0].definitions[3].e: We picked up a distress signal 6 km away.
distress.translation[1].definitions[0].d: to make someone feel very upset
distress.translation[1].definitions[0].e: The dream had distressed her greatly.
distress.translation[2].definitions[0].d: when someone’s goods are taken with the permission of a court of law so that they can be sold to pay unpaid rent, bills etc
distress.translation[2].definitions[0].e: The corporation had a power of absolute and immediate distress in the event of non-payment of dues.
